See also: Duschen

German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

See Dusche.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈduːʃən/ (standard)
  • IPA(key): /ˈdʊʃən/ (some speakers, perhaps dated)
  • audio
    		(file)

Verb[edit]

duschen (third-person singular simple present duscht, past tense duschte, past participle geduscht, auxiliary haben)

  1. (intransitive or reflexive) to shower
    Ich dusche (mich) jeden Tag.
    I shower every day.
  2. (transitive) to shower someone or something (e.g. a child, a portion of one's body)

Usage notes[edit]

  • The construction eine Dusche nehmen (literally “to take a shower”) is unusual, unlike ein Bad nehmen (“to take a bath”), which is common (though less so than baden).

Synonyms[edit]

  • brausen (rare)

Luxembourgish[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From the noun Dusch (“shower”), after French se doucher and German duschen.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈduʃen/, [ˈduʃən]

Verb[edit]

duschen (third-person singular present duscht, past participle geduscht, auxiliary verb hunn)

  1. to shower

Conjugation[edit]

Regular

participlegeduscht
auxiliaryhunn

indicative		imperative
1st singularduschen—
2nd singularduschsdusch

3rd pluralduschen—
(n) or (nn) indicates the Eifeler Regel.

Swedish[edit]

Noun[edit]

duschen

  1. definite singular of dusch
